name: Falcon Host API
description: This app allows you to manage indicators of compromise (IOC) and investigate your endpoints on the Falcon Host API

actions.description: Validate the asset configuration for connectivity
Hunt for a file on the network by querying for the hash
Get a list of device IDs on which the domain was matched
List processes that have recently used the IOC on a particular device
actions.verbose: Given a file hash or domain, the action will list all the processes that have either recently connected to the domain or interacted with the file that matches the supplied hash. Use the list endpoints actions to get the device id to run the action on.

ioc.description: File Hash or Domain to use for searching

id.description: Falcon Device ID to search on

actions.description: Retrieve the details of a process that is running or that previously ran, given a process ID

falcon_process_id.description: Process ID from previous Falcon IOC search

actions.description: Get details of a device, given the device ID

id.description: Device ID from previous Falcon IOC search

actions.description: Upload one or more indicators that you want CrowdStrike to watch
actions.verbose:
Valid values for the policy parameter are:
  • detect
    Send a notification when the particular indicator has been detected on a host
  • none
    Take no action when the particular indicator has been detected on a host. This is equivalent to turning the indicator off.

As of this writing the only valid value for the share_level parameter is red.
The expiration parameter is only valid for IP and Domains. As of this writing, if not specified, the Falcon API defaults to 30 days.

ioc.description: Input domain, ip or hash ioc

expiration.description: Alert lifetime in days (domains and ips only)

actions.description: Get the full definition of one or more indicators that are being watched

ioc.description: Hash, ip or domain IOC to get details of

actions.description: Update an indicator that has been uploaded

ioc.description: Hash, ip or domain IOC to update

expiration.description: Alert lifetime in days (domains and ips only)

actions.description: Delete an indicator that is being watched

ioc.description: Hash, ip or domain IOC from previous upload

actions.description: Get a list of uploaded IOCs that match the search criteria
actions.verbose:
The list of IOCs are segregated by the ioc type in the action results. The action view will limit the display of each IOC type to 100, however the result will contian the complete list returned by the device.
Valid and default values for parameters are:
  • type
    • all
      Search in all IOC types. This is the default
    • hash
      Search for match of type sha256, sha1 and md5
    • ipv4
    • sha256
    • sha1
    • md5
    • domain
  • policy
    Please see the documentation of the create alert action for an explaination of the policy values
    • all
      This is the default
    • detect
    • none
      This is a valid string value for the policy parameter
  • share_level
    • all
      This is the default
    • red

Every alert has an expiration time set (configured date and time when the alert will expire), use the from_expiration and to_expiration fields to return the alerts whose expiration time and date falls within the specified range. For e.g. to list all the alerts that expire between 1st August 2016 to 1st September 2016 use the from and to expiration dates as 2016-08-01T00:00:00Z and 2016-09-01T00:00:00Z respectively.

ioc.description: Hash, ip or domain IOC to match

actions.description: List all the endpoints/sensors configured on the device
actions.verbose:
Filtering:
The Filter parameter allows you to search for specific devices in your environment by platform, host name, IP, or a number of other parameters. The filter must be made in the format FIELD: ’VALUE’. The value for the field must be a string enclosed by single quotes:
platform_name:'Windows'

Some numerical fields support filtering with operators. Supported operators include: >, <, =, >=, <=, and != . Using filter operators, it is possible to conduct searches like; show me all devices that have been active in the 7 days before July 31 2016:
last_seen:>'2016-07-24'

Wildcards are also supported for host name search. For example, you could do a partial search for a device called "my-host-name" like so:
hostname:'my-host-na*'

You can also use multiple filter statements, the filters are applied sequentially, each search is executed and then the subsequent search is done over the filtered results.
There are two logical operators, a plus sign (+) is used for AND, and comma separated statements in brackets ([,]) are used for OR. Using logical operators, it is possible to conduct searches like; show me all devices that have been active in the 7 days before July 31 2016 AND devices where the platform is Windows OR Mac:
last_seen:>'2016-07-24'+platform_name:['Windows','Mac'].

actions.description: Set the state of a detection in Falcon Host
actions.verbose:
The detection id can be obtained from the Crowdstrike UI.
Valid values for the state parameter are new, in_progress, true_positive, false_positive and ignored.

id.description: Detection ID to set the state of
